description: From Middle English *overbreken, from Old English oferbrecan (“to transgress, violate”), equivalent to over- +‎ break.

entries.meaning: (civil engineering, geology) Rock or earth excavated beyond the planned extent; caving in of material near the edge of an excavation.

verbs.description: overbreak (third-person singular simple present overbreaks, present participle overbreaking, simple past overbroke, past participle overbroken)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cave in near the edge of an excavation.
examples: This proved wise as the south and west walls of the winder chamber overbroke badly and blocky ground was encountered in the area set aside for the electrical equipment.

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal) To get over; recover from.
examples: He was never able to overbreak his rheumatism.
